articles.headline: Winning South Carolina, Biden Makes Case Against Sanders: ‘Win Big or Lose’
articles.snippet: Joseph R. Biden Jr. drew on his decades-long relationships and leveraged his close bond with black voters to wrap up a state long considered his stronghold.
articles.abstract: Joseph R. Biden Jr. drew on his decades-long relationships and leveraged his close bond with black voters to wrap up a state long considered his stronghold.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. scored a decisive victory in the South Carolina primary on Saturday, reviving his listing campaign and establishing himself as the leading contender to slow Senator Bernie Sanders as the turbulent Democratic race turns to a slew of coast-to-coast contests on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Why Some Suburban Women Are Wary of Bernie Sanders
articles.snippet: Virginia’s shift to the Democrats has been led by suburban moderates, especially college-educated women. Some wonder whether Mr. Sanders is what they signed up for.
articles.abstract: Virginia’s shift to the Democrats has been led by suburban moderates, especially college-educated women. Some wonder whether Mr. Sanders is what they signed up for.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIRGINIA BEACH — In the Trump era, the suburbs have been Democrats’ surprising superpower.

articles.headline: Afghanistan War Enters New Stage as U.S. Military Prepares to Exit
articles.snippet: The deal signed on Saturday could have the United States conducting strikes to aid old enemies like the Taliban — or lead to a complete withdrawal from the country.
articles.abstract: The deal signed on Saturday could have the United States conducting strikes to aid old enemies like the Taliban — or lead to a complete withdrawal from the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Intelligence briefers regularly present President Trump with a classified map of Afghanistan, usually the only report on the war he examines, displaying the strikes carried out in recent days and, critically, the number of Taliban and other militants killed.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Milken Had Key Allies in Pardon Bid: Trump’s Inner Circle
articles.snippet: Rudolph Giuliani and Sheldon Adelson were among those who asked President Trump to pardon a symbol of 1980s greed.
articles.abstract: Rudolph Giuliani and Sheldon Adelson were among those who asked President Trump to pardon a symbol of 1980s greed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael Milken, a symbol of 1980s greed who went to prison for securities fraud and conspiracy, was at home in Encino, Calif., on Feb. 18 when he got a phone call from the White House. President Trump was on the line with good news: Mr. Milken had been pardoned.
articles.byline: By James B. Stewart and Jesse Drucker

articles.headline: Wall Street Has Lost Its Nerve. What Will It Take to Get It Back?
articles.snippet: The S&P 500 just had its worst week in more than a decade as investors fretted over the global coronavirus outbreak. The best cure may be time.
articles.abstract: The S&P 500 just had its worst week in more than a decade as investors fretted over the global coronavirus outbreak. The best cure may be time.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street has often adopted a simple playbook when facing a stock market plunge: “Buy the dip.” Not lately.

articles.headline: Intel’s Culture Needed Fixing. Its C.E.O. Is Shaking Things Up.
articles.snippet: Robert Swan, who leads the world’s biggest chip maker, is pushing his 110,000 employees to confront internal problems more openly.
articles.abstract: Robert Swan, who leads the world’s biggest chip maker, is pushing his 110,000 employees to confront internal problems more openly.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — Since last spring, workers at Intel who turned on their corporate laptops or wall displays inside the company’s more than 1,000 conference rooms have seen a new tagline: “One Intel.”

articles.headline: Why the Success of The New York Times May Be Bad News for Journalism
articles.snippet: In his debut, our new media columnist says The Times has become like Facebook or Google — a digital behemoth crowding out the competition.
articles.abstract: In his debut, our new media columnist says The Times has become like Facebook or Google — a digital behemoth crowding out the competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first time I met A.G. Sulzberger, the publisher of The New York Times, I tried to hire him.

articles.headline: In Coronavirus Fight, China Gives Citizens a Color Code, With Red Flags
articles.snippet: A new system uses software to dictate quarantines — and appears to send personal data to police, in a troubling precedent for automated social control.
articles.abstract: A new system uses software to dictate quarantines — and appears to send personal data to police, in a troubling precedent for automated social control.
articles.lead_paragraph: HANGZHOU, China — As China encourages people to return to work despite the coronavirus outbreak, it has begun a bold mass experiment in using data to regulate citizens’ lives — by requiring them to use software on their smartphones that dictates whether they should be quarantined or allowed into subways, malls and other public spaces.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur, Raymond Zhong and Aaron Krolik

articles.headline: As Buttigieg Exits Race, Biden Seeks Edge Against Sanders on Super Tuesday
articles.snippet: Mr. Biden was moving quickly to capitalize on his South Carolina victory and recast the Democratic primary campaign as a two-man contest between himself and Mr. Sanders.
articles.abstract: Mr. Biden was moving quickly to capitalize on his South Carolina victory and recast the Democratic primary campaign as a two-man contest between himself and Mr. Sanders.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher and Reid J. Epstein

articles.headline: 2nd Death Near Seattle Adds to Signs Virus Is Spreading in U.S.
articles.snippet: Officials see growing indications that the coronavirus has been spreading undetected for weeks. A cluster of cases at one nursing home have made Kirkland, Wash., a focus of concern.
articles.abstract: Officials see growing indications that the coronavirus has been spreading undetected for weeks. A cluster of cases at one nursing home have made Kirkland, Wash., a focus of concern.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow the latest on coronavirus in the U.S.
articles.byline: By Mike Baker, Sheri Fink, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Jack Healy

articles.headline: Can YouTube Quiet Its Conspiracy Theorists?
articles.snippet: A new study examines YouTube’s efforts to limit the spread of conspiracy theories on its site, from videos claiming the end times are near to those questioning climate change.
articles.abstract: A new study examines YouTube’s efforts to limit the spread of conspiracy theories on its site, from videos claiming the end times are near to those questioning climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new study examines YouTube’s efforts to limit the spread of conspiracy theories on its site, from videos claiming the end times are near to those questioning climate change.

articles.headline: Global Economic Policymakers Scramble as Coronavirus Threatens Growth
articles.snippet: Economists slashed growth forecasts, and officials rushed to put a floor under the impending damage.
articles.abstract: Economists slashed growth forecasts, and officials rushed to put a floor under the impending damage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Global policymakers moved to ease public anxiety over the coming economic hit from the coronavirus on Monday, as analysts warned of a severe slowdown in growth and a possible recession if the virus continued to spread.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Jack Welch, G.E. Chief Who Became a Business Superstar, Dies at 84
articles.snippet: Mr. Welch was named “manager of the century” after General Electric’s revenue jumped nearly fivefold during his tenure.
articles.abstract: Mr. Welch was named “manager of the century” after General Electric’s revenue jumped nearly fivefold during his tenure.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jack Welch, who led General Electric through two decades of extraordinary corporate prosperity and became the most influential business manager of his generation, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

articles.headline: Supreme Court to Hear Obamacare Appeal
articles.snippet: The Affordable Care Act, which has survived two major challenges in the Supreme Court, faces another test.
articles.abstract: The Affordable Care Act, which has survived two major challenges in the Supreme Court, faces another test.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to hear a third major challenge to the Affordable Care Act, setting up likely arguments this fall in a case that could wipe out President Barack Obama’s signature domestic achievement.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Abby Goodnough
